Once you get over the fact of trying to get one castle you really have to learn how to protect that castle. You need to be some kind of wizard, which I suppose you can be once you level up quite nicely with some faction which you have dedicated so much time leveling up with to rake in hundreds of fresh recruits, taking them to a training place, spending hours to make them from recruit to seasoned knight or foot guard or expert archer or crossbowman, then to go right back to the castle, drop them off so that when some stuckup bigoted lord decides to park his horse right up your castle, you can have a chance to keep the castle you so miraclously and painstakingly won. Politics and domination aside, the actual fighting of Mount and blade can be quite great and boring. Never have I ever felt so much fun trying to master blocking an up hit when I always go sideways block. Quite frustrating at first but then I just laugh it off. It is also a bit annoying when playing singleplayer matches with other lords when you really need a horse to actually survive the match. You can risk getting your head severed by some big burly knight that ravishes you like last night's dinner if you are on foot. If you use your head you can go behind  some of your troops, pick up a bow or crossbow or a pike and fend them off a bit. The mods really make the difference to the game. Having mods such as Diplomacy really make the game interesting, as you can actually have some Automated micromanagement of your Kingdom. It's really great for singleplayer! I never had so much enjoyment sending my Recruitment officer out to get 100 fresh recruits from any faction you want and they come back in about a week and then spend each day recruiting some recruits up to some seasoned warriors, and plus without you doing anything. It's great really to do that. It's also great if you prefer the poltical side of things, such as buying out kings or using other kinds of diplomacy to pave your way. I also found that once you become a king of some scrapple of a kingdom you own, It is highly difficult to get recognised as a king if you attempt to become one early on in the game. You really need to depend on royals and other npc follower characters which can spread some word about deeds you will do so you can gain more right to rule. If you don't have enough right to rule Kings will just laugh at your face if you send them a messenger asking for peace when they are busting your back side with 300 soldiers that are pillaging your poor poor villages. It is quite demoralising when you ask the King for peace and he just casually says, " You want peace? Then trip on your sword." Oh thanks king you just really made my day haven't you? You just promoted healthy living and state of mind for myself. I have a million things to do as King and you are not helping! Essentially, the game becomes your life. You spend most your free days just playing, becoming one with Mount and Blade. Eventually you just get sucked into this Warband Complex and you become that random charcter you been playing all this time. Now, after a brief overview of the Singleplayer side of things, Mutliplayer is really really great if you have a very good patience. Sometimes it just might be that guy everyone calls the "Xbow" who just sits on that corner of the map and has a chip on his shoulder and decides to let out steam by shooting you in the head all the time. Why he always picks on one target I do not know. Or the fact that all the major clans in the game are dead is also another matter to note. Despite that if you are Australian there is always a server up with under 100 ping to play on which the map is primarily set on the "Arena". It's a really small map but that is so great imagine spending five minutes trying to find some guy that ends up killing you with a two handed weapon anyway. This leads me to come onto weapons. They can be unbalanced sometimes, most of the times. Maybe it's the fact that a two handed sword can be nearly as quick swinging as a one hander sword but that's another problem. There is another problem that really annoys me is the lack of experience a whole lot of players have. The players that usually have experience are people in clans. Others just spam you with bows or two handers.

												I could say that I recommend this game but only for the " single-player "Multiplayer looks like this :#1 - Deathmatch = ½Why? It's just a regular deathmatch, you choose weapons and armor, earn by killing others etc. and your job is to...kill enemy nothing else.#2 - Fighting = ¼It's pretty bugged because you can spam with your attack animation making you unable to notice from which side actually enemy will attack. Looks like your enemy tries to strike you from right? You're wrong, he attacks you from above. That's the problem in fighting.Singleplayer :#1 - Story = ¿I can't actually tell if this game has a story, you're just in " Calradia " and there are few nations that will try to take lands from each other. You have three options - 1.Join nation and fight for your king   2.Make your own faction and try to capture each castle ( it's the hardest option ) 3.Meet claimants and help them recover their position then fight for them ( for some time they will stay in your party and be your soldier ). You can change it at anytime, you can be vassal one day and next day you'll make your own faction or you can help a claimant recover his throne then join a faction and fights against him.#2 - Battles = ½It's just a regular battle but if you're cavalry...AI is really stupid, even when you choose the hardest options they are still imbeciles. They maybe have the power to knock you out with one hit when on horse but, it's easy to outsmart them. If you're using cavalry you're mostly impossible to lose a fight ( of course if you use mods to watch fights after being KOed ) since cavalry is OP you don't have to focus on archers or infantry but the problem with AI difficulty comes when you're trying to siege castle. They start to think, use shields and attack you in right time, also they will try to move back or charge at you etc.If you're playing on easy then you just go with your sword like with a knife into a butter.#3 - Castles = ¾They look nice from inside when you're visiting towns but... It's really annoying when you're walking around streets for 2-3 mins searching for guild master ( yes there are mods which help with this but still you're supposed to meet them atleast once ) Sometimes when you visit castle and you want to talk with for example a fellow vassal then you have go through all the castle then go upstairs ( Nords )#4 - Trading = ½It's pretty nice that you can sell your stuff on marketplace but they have only limitted amount of denars ( currency )But there are bugs like :-You have armor with 52 body protection and 12 leg protection - It's worth like 5.000 denars to buy but 800 to sell?also buying armor with 54 body protection and 14 leg protection in the same marketplace is worth sometimes even like 80.000 denars so the hell is that?#5 - Units = ⅞About units, it's possible to notice difference in a normal soldier and veteran soldier, veteran has more damage, he moves back, uses block more often etc. while normal soldier is stupid and he just charges at you blocking your attacks like one per ten hits. They all look great and i really love how each faction has their own type of soldiers, for example. Rhodoks = Crossbowmans   Nords = Infantry   Swadia = Heavy cavalry.I recommend but I don't, use stuff i wrote as help to decide if you want to buy this game.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2010
												So you've played every popular multiplayer FPS under the sun and are looking to ditch the guns in favor of something a bit more personal.   Well, this is the game for you.  Pick up your favorite melee weapon and get up close to your enemy so you can see that look on his face just before you stab him in it.  A good analogy for how multiplayer works in this game is Counterstrike without the guns.  You start each round with a set amount of cash and some free equipment and then pick and choose between your nation's weapons/armor of choice and then take to the field and try not to get yourself killed while hopefully taking a few of the enemy out along the way.  In addition to excellent infantry related combat, archery, cavalry and horse-archery are all represented as well if being a ground pounder isn't your thing. Also, although the multiplayer is a real blast, the game also features a great sandbox-style (think Sid Meier's Pirates) singleplayer game where you start off as a lowly peasant and work your way up to leading huge armies and ruling your own kingdom. There is no linear storyline or hand-holding you here, the game is what you make of it. If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play a general from the Total War series from a first or third person perspective, this game will somewhat give you that experience. If you have a high-end gaming rig, you can set the battle size up to like 500+ units on screen at once (with a small third-party tool). The game's graphics aren't on the cutting edge of current technology, but they allow for huge battles.  Where the game really shines is in its combat.  It's one of the few games I've ever seen where you control your attack/block directions.  Watching 2 pro's go at it is akin to watching a well coreographed movie fight.I cannot recommend this game enough. You just don't see GOOD medieval combat anywhere really. This isn't some button hammering console combat game. Check out the demo!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
 Introduction I have been playing Mount and Blades: Warband for quite awhile now. And as I played I gained to love the Single Player with or without mods and Love the Multiplayer whether I am playing alone, with friends or with a regiment making new friends on the DLC Napoleonic Wars. But here I am going to be talking about Mount and Blades: Warband the best medieval simulator until the next Mount and Blade game which is Bannerlord. And this review will hopefully make you spend some worthwhile and unregretable cash on this simple yet advanced game that is Mount and Blades: Warband. The Game You first have a couple of options that determine your class, gender, skills, your family linege, your upbringing and your early adult/teenage life before setting out on a grand adventure. This game puts you smack bang in the middle of an ever changing world full of conquest, betrayals, trade, conflict and so much more that you have to descover yourself :). Will you be a merchant where your goal is to make as much coin and possible. Will you become a bandit pillaging the lands of Nobles. Will you become a man of Honor and fight for a just cause or will you do anything to get to the throne if that means cheating your way :3 (I recommend using mods as the choices are endless with many improvements). And many more options, the choice is yours. Graphics The graphics on the game are quite outdated and I give credit for the Devs for putting so much detail anyway regardless. This game was not made by a triple A title however the graphics are not too bad on High settings and with GFX enhancement mods. Nontheless the graphics don't make the game, as it has not really effected me much I love the game  with low settings as I played this on my Craptop but thats my opinion because I know people only care about the graphics...and if you ask me they are filthy casuals xD. But for real don't judge a game by it's graphics or the cover. Pros   Combat system  Medieval immersion  Unpredictable gameplay High replayable Open world Highly customisable Mods Visual mods Active cummunity Native/DLC Quite a challange "Fair, This is Calradia boy" -Merchant Difficulty CAN be reduced or increased Multiplayer is active and very fun LOW SPECS WANTED, yes if you have Low specs on your PC this game can most likely handle it Cons  Combat System is easy to learn but hard the master  Multiplayer is very hard for new players  The game is HARD in Single Player and is very unforgiving (I like this personally but I am use to it, when I first started playing I hated how unforgiving it was) Graphics without Visual Enhancement Mods AI can be quite dumb (Depends on your settings) And the last CON is the fact that you have not bought :3. In Conclusion  In conclusion this game is a blast with or without mods. But in my opinion you HAVE to get mods after you have played native or before...after all it's your choice. But with MODS you can do so much more that makes the game a 1000 times better with Politics, combat and much more. However I am not hating on NATIVE (without mods) because I started this game without mods and I still loved it, and you should too. If you are into medieval simulation and want to hack down a few bandits with your longsword GO RIGHT AHEAD. This game is by far one of the best games I have played EVER. It is everything you NEED for an amazing medieval game. Mount and Blades: Warband in simply ENDLESS of what you can do. The strategic options are very advanced and will punish if you make a wrong move. My final verdict for the game is a 9/10 for it is the BEST MEDIEVAL GAME OUT THERE TO THIS DATE.Drops mic....

content:

												For summer vacation, the Waits family has decided to vacation in the town of Nilbog, a remote farming community, where they will swap houses with one of the local residents and spend the summer living off of the land. Young Joshua Waits (Michael Stephenson) is contacted by the ghost of his dead grandfather, Seth (Robert Ormsby), who warns him about monsters known as goblins — malicious vegetarians who turn people into human/plant hybrids in order to eat them.Meanwhile, Joshua's sister, Holly (Connie McFarland), receives a visit from her boyfriend Elliot (Jason Wright), with whom she has been having relationship problems: Holly is concerned that Elliot spends too much time with his friends. Elliot assures Holly of his love for her, and tells her that he will prove it by accompanying her family to Nilbog.The next morning, Elliot fails to show up at the Waits house; parents Michael (George Hardy) and Diane (Margo Prey) grow impatient waiting for him to arrive, and the family departs for Nilbog. En route they meet up with Elliot, who has decided to bring along his friends Brent (David McConnell), Arnold (Darren Ewing) and Drew (Jason Steadman) in an RV. The family also runs across a hitchhiker whom Grandpa Seth uses as a medium to channel himself, warning Joshua that the town of Nilbog is the Kingdom of Goblins and that his family has been lured there to be made into food.Arriving in Nilbog, the Waits family discovers that the residents have left a large, all-vegetable meal for them. Grandpa Seth appears again, freezing time and warning Joshua that the food is actually a potion that will turn them into vegetable people. When time resumes, Joshua jumps on the table and urinates on all of the food.Meanwhile, Arnold takes a walk in the woods outside of Nilbog and runs into a woman, Cindy, being pursued by goblins. They seek shelter in a chapel that turns out to be the residence of Creedence Leonore Gielgud (Deborah Reed), who feeds them a goblin potion—the woman disintegrates into a mass of green ectoplasm, while Arnold becomes a plant/human hybrid. Creedence reveals herself to be the druid queen of the goblins, whose "Stonehenge Magic Stone" is the source of all the goblins' power; a horrified Arnold watches as goblins consume the ectoplasm, realizing that he will be next. Although Drew ultimately finds him and attempts to free him, he is killed by Creedence.That night, Holly is unintentionally contacted by Seth via a mirror and she and Joshua swap rooms. On Seth's instructions, Joshua destroys all of the food in the house, which only results in Michael taking him on a trip to the town general store the next morning. They find the store closed, with all the town's inhabitants attending a "sermon" about the evils of eating meat held by the town's demonic preacher. Joshua sneaks away to the church where the goblins have congregated. The goblins capture Joshua and attempt to feed him ice cream spiked with goblin potion, but Michael arrives, prompting the goblins to let Joshua go. A suspicious Joshua and Michael return home, only for the family to be met by seemingly the entire town of Nilbog, who want to throw them a party. Joshua runs upstairs to try to contact Grandpa Seth through the mirror, only to be confronted by Creedence in goblin form. Grandpa Seth suddenly appears out of thin air and chops off Creedence's hand with an axe, prompting her to retreat.Grandpa Seth and Joshua go back downstairs to prevent the family from eating any food. The town preacher (Mike Hamill) attempts to stop them by trying to banish Seth to Hell, but Seth causes a magic lightning bolts to ignite a molotov cocktail, killing the preacher. When the preacher dies, he transforms into his true, goblin form; Seth's presence and the sight of the dead goblin finally convince the family that they are in danger. Seth disappears, and the family barricade themselves inside the house.Meanwhile, Creedence transforms herself into a beautiful young woman and appears at Elliot's RV in an exotic negligee, where she seduces Brent using an ear of corn. As they begin to have sex, the corn spontaneously explodes into a flood of popcorn. Brent is quickly swallowed up and left immobilized but alive; with the family's last hope of rescue neutralized, Creedence heads back to her chapel.Back at the house, Joshua, Elliot, Holly, Michael and Diane hold a séance to communicate with Seth. Seth appears and tells them that in 10 minutes he will be permanently cut off from the mortal world. Although goblins invade the house and kidnap Joshua, Seth is able to pass him a backpack, which Seth informs him has a weapon that will save him from mortal danger; he is further able to tell Joshua that if he can touch the Stonehenge Magic Stone, it will drain the goblins of their power.In Creedence's chapel, Joshua opens the backpack and discovers a bologna sandwich. He eats it, "tainting" his blood with meat and preventing the goblins from consuming him. The Waitses and Elliot then arrive and, together, they all touch the Stonehenge Magic Stone, destroying Creedence and all of her goblins.The next day, the Waits family heads back home; Diane eats food in their refrigerator, not realizing that it was placed there by the family with whom they exchanged houses. She is transformed into a human/plant hybrid and eaten by the remaining goblin family; the film ends with a screaming Joshua being offered a piece of his mother's corpse to eat.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This was my first entry into the Mount & Blade series, instantly becoming a favourite of mine. This is a fairly low-budget, open world RPG in which you create a relatively simple player background, leaving much to be created in your own imagination. While some may see this as a limitation, it's also a huge advantage for people who want to create their own identity within the game and focus on role-playing. You also choose one of the regions to start in, all of which have their strengths and limitations, for instance Vaegir are great at ranged combat, but not so skilled with two-handed weapons. Although this doesn't effect your character's abilities, simply the types of enemies and available weaponry. Part of what makes this game so great is the fact that you could literally role-play anything you wanted; an honourable knight, a brutal raider, or anything inbetween. You slowly build up your band of warriors and complete quests. You start earning the real money when you join your first military campaign by swearing an oath to a king. You can lead on to amassing an empire of property and riches, conquering the world map and even become a king yourself (with enough time of course)The combat system is by far the highlight of the game, with excellent sword-play both on and off horseback. It doesn't over-complicate things while keeping you fully invested in the battles. While archery is fun, I find it to be nothing too special, and if the enemies go heavy on shields, it's really hard to hit anything.The two DLCs seem to be hit-or-miss however, Napoleonic Wars is only multiplayer, so unless you get really into that it's not worth it. Viking Conquest looks like it could be great, but it's filled with unsolved bugs. [EDIT: Viking Conquest Reforged seems to have resolved many issues, but still, buyers beware.]There is also an array of excellent workshop items and mods that completley transform the games setting, graphics and even overhaul the entire combat system with the game allowing you to switch between mods the the original game wth a simple drop down menu, giving immense amounts of replayability. I highly recommend picking up the core game as soon as possible.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Mount and Blade: Warband is the game that the original Mount and Blade wanted to be when it was released.  More polished, more complete, and in all ways improved, this is the best swording-mans simulator on the market.  The modding community is fantastic, offering new maps, troop trees, fief management options, etc.  The only remaining glaring weakness is companion management - in the game, your companions will not automatically equip themselves with improved gear (though many mods add this as a feature) and it is next to impossible to know, without switching through multiple screens, whether a particular weapon or piece of armor in a shop is an improvment over what your companions are currently using.I have sunk more hours into the Mount and Blade series in the past couple of years than into every other non-MMO game combined.  If you haven't bough and played it, yet, you are truly missing out on one of the singular gaming experiences of today.

												How do I describe how good Mount and Blade: Warband is? It's difficult to say because it's not the native version of the game itself that is so amazing. Yeah it's fun, and definitely worth the price tag as it is. 60 or so hours worth of fun I would say, but I am rapidly approaching and will definitely surpass the 600 hour mark soon. Why? Because it is like a canvas, the native game introduces gameplay mechanics that have a lot of potential for variety once it's in the hands of the modding community. I'm no modder myself so I can't speak to how hard or easy it is to mod the game, but the general idea of commanding an army on a battlefield in a third or first person perspective lends itself well to a lot of different ways to engage in battle. I had 40-60 hrs in native, another 200 in the viking conquest expansion ($14.95 atm I think) which is a lot of fun and worth the price tag, and the rest in the many various mods of the game. There are mods for just about any sort of warfare from Roman times up to the Civil War. There are mods for fantasy settings and even a LoTR mod. There is so much to offer a person inclined to like this sort of game. It can be a bit difficult when first learning the game, so don't let that get you down, just look stuff up and keep at it and you'll be engaging in large (in viking conquest at least with troop on field limits of 750 as opposed to the 150 of native) battles. You have to recruit, pay, train, upgrade your units, manage companions, your own character, villages, towns, castles, and even a kingdom later on if you manage to establish yourself. It's a bit to learn and sometimes it is hard early on to get a foothold, but the game is worth the time getting to know it. The actual combat seems stange at first, but becomes rather intuitive once you get a handle on it, and having tested all the weapon types, they're all useful in one situation or another, but I tend to learn towards swords and pole-arms as being mounted is important for a commander and those weapons lend well to such combat. Archery is fun, too, but that takes a lot of practice to be viable.I rate gameplay 10/10, look to other reviews for other factors like graphics because as long as I know what I'm looking at, graphics quality doesn't mean so much to me.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												After having pumped 200+ hours into the game I think I should write a review to support the game, so here I go.Mount & Blade Warband, released in 2010, a kind-of sequel to the original Mount & Blade, is a First/Third Person Action RPG/RTS set in a medieval open world. You set your own goal - live a life as a mercenary, become a Lord of one of the kingdoms, join a claimant to a throne in his battle to take, as he/she thinks, his/her rightful place as king, or go against all of the kingdoms and create your own.You start the game completely on your own in one of the capital cities of your liking where you happen to get your first quest. You then recruit soldiers for your troop and either be a good samaritan who takes care of the bandits and helps villages, or be the feared vandal by raiding caravans and villages.Now, putting together your troop and controlling it in battle is where the RTS part comes in.All your soldiers can be put in groups (similar to ordinary RTS control groups which you select with the 0-9 keys) to always only select those soldiers you want, giving you a lot of control over them. In battles you can give them all sorts of commands you could think of, including, but not limited to, telling them to use only certain weapons that they possess.Another special thing about this game is the very skill-based combat system.The melee combat system is based on attacking from four directions and being able to block them - of course by blocking in the direction the swing comes from. This can be really tough sometimes when there's a lot of stuff going on or if your opponent has a rather fast weapon.You can set up how you want to swing and block independently. Do you want it to work by going into the corresponding direction? Or only by mouse movement?In singleplayer, for beginners, you can even enable automatic blocking. This will result in you only having to press the block button when a swing comes in, of course you still have to know when to block and when to swing. This setting does not apply to multiplayer though, there it is up to the server wether there's automatic blocking or not - but most likely you'll only be seeing automatic blocking in player vs bot games (there are special modules that are based on fending off enemy waves with other players).The multiplayer mode is something that first came with Warband, and I think it's pretty solid for an indie game (except for some minor things, but later onto that).It supports up to 250 players and several modes, including Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, Last man standing Deathmatch and of course castle siege, similar to sieging a castle in singleplayer.Apart from all that great stuff the game also has an amazing mod support. Search moddb.com for Mount & Blade mods (for both the original game and Warband) and you'll understand what I mean.As many pros as this game has, it also has a few cons.A big problem in multiplayer, similar to other games (like Chivalry, for example), are the trolls.There are a lot of times when you have a lot of fun and fight a bunch of great battles, and then there's the trolls' prime time.At that time, things are going to get messy. You randomly get hit, shot and kicked by a teammate just to annoy you and then that person just runs along as if nothing happened. When you try to take revenge, they will turn things around and make you look like the vermin, causing everyone to go at you. Classy trolls.That's about the negatives I could think of and it isn't really the games' fault.To round this review of, I'll give a short summary:Pros:-solid melee combat system-troop management-good graphics (remember that this was and still is an indie game - I think the graphics are absolutely fine despite what others have said. Besides, the graphics in M&BII have been improved by a lot.)-great multiplayer with a high number of players supported and several gamemodes-mod support-always challengingCons:-engine limitationsSo I come to the conclusion that I can clearly recommend this title to others. Also keep an eye out for the upcoming sequel!

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
 Note: I have been away from this game for a small amount of time, so excuse me if some of the information I give you is incorrect.  General If you don't like medieval games, this game is the last thing you'd want. This game is both third person and first person. There are 3 main classes with every unit in the game, including in multiplayer. The three classes are  Infantry, Archers, and Horseman.  the weapon usage varies with each class. The factions are  Vaegirs, Rhodoks, Swadians, Sarranids, Nords, and Khergits.  These factions are constantly at war with each other. You can affect the game in a massive way, or a small way. In both singleplayer and multiplayer, people can affect you and you can affect people in a variety of ways. From covering an archer as an infantry class to covering infantry as a horseman class, the customization is a great part of the game. The graphics are obviously not the best, but that's just what you get with an older game. Don't let that control your whole opinion of the game. There are no real spoilers to the game, as there is no hand-holding, or "missions". There are quests, but you can choose to take them. Singleplayer Singleplayer is a great part of the game that not many people will get bored of right after starting. You start out with a small band of men that are only able to defeat bandits, which can eventually turn into a 300 man army attacking a rival king. You have the choice to do whatever you want. If you allign to a faction for the purpose of destroying it, you can slide your way up the ranks, and get people to rebel from the faction with you, or just work your way up by taking a city by yourself. Multiplayer Multiplayer has a series of game modes, from dueling to sieges. A good amount of the players are veterans, and can teach you whatever you want to know. That's how I got a lot of my experience in multiplayer. Multiplayer is very similar to singleplayer, but in my opinion, better. It actually feels immersive, as you have an actual challenge. I don't feel very comfortable killing AI, as it doesn't feel real enough to me. In my opinion, multiplayer is better than singleplayer to me in every way. Even though there is no map, the battles feel much better in all aspects. Napoleonic Wars Napoleonic Wars, the DLC for Mount and Blade: Warband, is fantastic.  NOTE: There is no Singleplayer for Napoleonic Wars.  Even there is no singleplayer for NW, the multiplayer is great. Most of the combat that happens is ranged, as there are muskets in the game. All muskets are able to switch to melee mode with X, which helps out a lot, rather than having a fist fight in the middle of a classical battle (which is possible as well). Many of the maps are made by the community. The addition of cannons, swivel guns, and mortars really helps out with taking out many men at once. It is unbelievably easy to get attached to. In my opinion, the DLC is at a good price, for the amount of content included in it. Conclusion Overall, the game is completely worth the price, along with Napoleonic Wars. If you would like to know more about the game/DLC than I explained, just message me, and i'll help you out. Thanks for reading me review on Mount and Blade: Warband and Napoleonic Wars.

Posted: July 23, 2012
												Mount & Blade: Warband is one of the best games I have played in a while. The combat is solid, the factions have their own strengths and weaknesses and the battles are hectic and massive. This is one of the only games I have seen that actually lets you be part of the battle instead of some sort of skygod. Did I say the battles were awesome yet? If I did let me say it again, the battles can range from small skirmishes to large scale battles. In addition to the field battles you also have the ability to seige castles and cities and if that isn't your style, why not raid a few peasent villages for loot and plunder!There are countless things I could say that are good about Mount & Blade: Warband including the Mod support. Like Game of Thrones? The have a mod for that. Want the game to take place in Feudal Europe? They have a mod for that as well! There are a bunch of other mods for the game so the replay value is extremely high.The game does have a couple of downsides though.One of them being the graphics. If you are looking for a visually stunning game this may not be for you. Along with that there is very little voice acting. The only voice acting you will hear are the warcrys of the soliders on the battlefield and the bandits as well as some farmers, so don't be expecting Morgan Freeman or Jennifer Hale as voice actors and voice actresses.The early game is quite difficult as well (or at least it was for me.) You will constantly be attacked by Bandits, Sea Raiders and the like until you amass a big enough force to take them and then still they will  sometimes attack you.But if you can look past these flaws I think you will have a great time. I know I did! Thank you for reading my review for the great game and I am sorry if this review isn't that great as it is my first review!Thanks for your time.Best regards-A Crazed Engineer

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Wow this is a difficult game to describe. A sandbox action RPG set in a medieval land (fantasy, but realistic- no dragons, elves etc). After creating a character and completing a couple of short quests, the world is basically yours to explore and you can play as you please. You get money and/or xp by hunting bandits, pillaging, trading, selling prisoners, fighting tournaments, completing quests... and much more besides.There are 6 factions all competing for control of the realm. You may decided to ally yourself with one of them, serving the King as a vassal, fighting his wars and seizing towns and castles. You may decided to assist a claimant to the throne, creating a rebel faction to usurp the current King, or you may proclaim youself King and create your own faction. Be aware that this is a dynamic and ever changing world- relations rise and fall, lands are conquered or pillaged, and lords may betray their King and defect. Every action has a consequence.The game world is presented in a basic overworld map, switching to 3rd person upon entering a town, castle or village, or when in combat. The combat itself is the real meat of the game, allowing the player to swing, thrust or chop depending on the movement of the mouse. Riding on horseback also adds to the fun factor, and learning to time your strike as you gallop towards the enemy is key.You may also recruit militia and companions into your party, and they will join you on the battlefield. They can be given commands (such as follow, hold and charge) and will also earn xp and level up. The command system is simple, but works well. If you don't want to get blood on your shiny new armour then sending your troops ahead to fight without you is often a legitimate option.The game does have a few quirks that will annoy some people (such as companions bickering, complaining and abandoning you). Fortunately there is a program available to download (TweakMB) that allows you to easily tailor the gameplay mechanics to better suit you.Buy this game if you enjoy solid combat, open-ended gameplay and epic battles.

												Title: "Me and another man's wife: A trip 'round Calradia."Lord Gundar or something was not in good terms with me.So I asked him if he had any task for me. Well enough he wished for me to escort his wife from Praven to Uxkhal expecting her to be well guarded under my war party. Well all right, hope he would then like me more.I went into the Tavern buying best wine for everyone that night. Went to the market doing usual stuffs selling and buying weapons/horses/armors/ and cheese for my cohorts. There was no war going on so I must have got sidetracked or something. I went then to the Nord territory hopefully to train some recruits into Huscarls. Going round and round each village and town.Damn it hit me then I forgot about Gundar's wife! Lady Isna......well she's still in my company and there's like 15 days left. Plenty of time no problem. It'd be good to show her around the country a bit. Hang in there lady.Two days later we arrived at Sargoth hey there's a tournament going on. Oh man how I love tournaments, so we joined, I and all my cohorts. Sweet, placed the bet, awesome! I clicked "View Participants". OMG Lady Isna has just joined the tourney! LOLOL big time. Damn she'd probably wouldn't last the first tier.So simple enough, I have got pretty good at tourneys so I won the first round and second too. Curious enough I checked again the remaining participants. OH SHE'S still IN!! WHAT THE HELL, OLD GAL?!Went into the arena again, this time I try to look at the logs on the screen and BAM! Lady Champion Fighter knocked out by Lady Isna!!! OMG Gundar, did you know that your wife is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ female warrior!! xD xD :O!!!! Defying all expectations, she made it to the final. Unbelievable! This is it! You or me lady Isna. I have never given this much thought to a female NPC in the game before, and that includes my wife Lady Elys who's awaiting my return at Suno.We both got a shield and an axe. She came right charging in.....man a lord's wife has never been more terrifying. I sidestepped evading her overhead plunge then kick her with the "E" button, and finished it off with a slam from the right. BAM!....I won with a single hit. God who would have thought a Lord's wife with hitpoints so low would make it to the final.Hmm all right, time to really get to work. I probably shouldn't screw this quest up. Checked my quest notes. Oh we still have like 13 days to take her to Uxkhal......Or..........we could go round the country doing tourneys together :D :D. So long story short, that's what we did. Went to a couple more tournaments/attacked some bandits together. And suddenly, the Nord declared war on the Kingdom of Swadia, so I took her finally to Uxkhal and we exchanged good byes. She said she hoped to see me again.To tell the truth, it was a bit disheartening to see her go. It was rather a fun thing to do during peace time. I could not have asked for anything more :D. A call to arms from our Marshal, I made ready my troops and prepare for another journey to war.At the back of my mind I still remember her charging at me from the first tourney, and it left me wondering why would she need an escort in the first place.........1000000000/10 would escort another man's wife to tourneys again.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
 Note: I have been away from this game for a small amount of time, so excuse me if some of the information I give you is incorrect.  General If you don't like medieval games, this game is the last thing you'd want. This game is both third person and first person. There are 3 main classes with every unit in the game, including in multiplayer. The three classes are  Infantry, Archers, and Horseman.  the weapon usage varies with each class. The factions are  Vaegirs, Rhodoks, Swadians, Sarranids, Nords, and Khergits.  These factions are constantly at war with each other. You can affect the game in a massive way, or a small way. In both singleplayer and multiplayer, people can affect you and you can affect people in a variety of ways. From covering an archer as an infantry class to covering infantry as a horseman class, the customization is a great part of the game. The graphics are obviously not the best, but that's just what you get with an older game. Don't let that control your whole opinion of the game. There are no real spoilers to the game, as there is no hand-holding, or "missions". There are quests, but you can choose to take them. Singleplayer Singleplayer is a great part of the game that not many people will get bored of right after starting. You start out with a small band of men that are only able to defeat bandits, which can eventually turn into a 300 man army attacking a rival king. You have the choice to do whatever you want. If you allign to a faction for the purpose of destroying it, you can slide your way up the ranks, and get people to rebel from the faction with you, or just work your way up by taking a city by yourself. Multiplayer Multiplayer has a series of game modes, from dueling to sieges. A good amount of the players are veterans, and can teach you whatever you want to know. That's how I got a lot of my experience in multiplayer. Multiplayer is very similar to singleplayer, but in my opinion, better. It actually feels immersive, as you have an actual challenge. I don't feel very comfortable killing AI, as it doesn't feel real enough to me. In my opinion, multiplayer is better than singleplayer to me in every way. Even though there is no map, the battles feel much better in all aspects. Napoleonic Wars Napoleonic Wars, the DLC for Mount and Blade: Warband, is fantastic.  NOTE: There is no Singleplayer for Napoleonic Wars.  Even there is no singleplayer for NW, the multiplayer is great. Most of the combat that happens is ranged, as there are muskets in the game. All muskets are able to switch to melee mode with X, which helps out a lot, rather than having a fist fight in the middle of a classical battle (which is possible as well). Many of the maps are made by the community. The addition of cannons, swivel guns, and mortars really helps out with taking out many men at once. It is unbelievably easy to get attached to. In my opinion, the DLC is at a good price, for the amount of content included in it. Conclusion Overall, the game is completely worth the price, along with Napoleonic Wars. If you would like to know more about the game/DLC than I explained, just message me, and i'll help you out. Thanks for reading me review on Mount and Blade: Warband and Napoleonic Wars.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												One of the more innovative games I've played in recent years, Mount and Blade combines strategy and real-time 1st person combat beautifully. The combat is unique, and certainly has a learning curve to become accustomed to the attack timing of swings and so on, but it is very fun when you get the hang of it. Bows and crossbows are a well-functioning mechanic, as well as the sword and board aspect. Lancers, spearmen and viking nords are even effective and playable in some situations. Castle sieges are much fun, however the AI could sometimes use work in how the army maneuvers up ladders and into castles, as they have a mob mentality where all forces tend to focus on one group of enemies exclusively, occasionally to the detriment of the whole if they are being picked off by tower archers or bottlenecked and beaten one by one.This game has some wonderful mods, some that greatly reduce the micro-management aspects, some that go to great lengths to fix some of the finer details that were probably not given the development time they deserved in the original such as trading, the mechanics of politics and allied heroes for hire. There are literally hundreds of mods for this game that span everything from different wars, regions and times to crossover reworks such as turning Mount and Blade into the Star Wars universe or The Walking Dead. One mod I would highly recommend is called the "native expansion" mod for Mount and Blade, and it doesn't change the basica gameplay or mechanics, but it adds heaps of new troop types, including the ability to fight against and hire elite troops, expands the trading aspects greatly, increases village upgrade and management options, and fixes many bugs from the original. It also adds death knights, if you're feeling tough. You might not be after you face them.The end-game in the conquer the world campaign is a bit lackluster, as you often end up at a certain point in the game where you reach a peak of sorts regarding controlled castles/towns and it feels as though you are treading water, constantly running around to defeat huge armies of other kingdoms so they do not retake old properties while you are trying to expand to new places. This is a balance issue with the kingdoms armies and your hired heroes who you've sent off to patrol different areas as liege lords.It has some drawbacks, the biggest being that the way it is built really does not allow for multiplayer beyond single scenario sieges (first person pvp battles). The strategy portion of the game (riding around the kingdom trading, negotiating, questing, conquering) is built in such a way that whenever the player stops the game is paused, so any sort of multiplayer in this sense would be incredibly difficult if not impossible to sync up, without butchering it into a turn-based shell of itself which I cannot imagine would play well. Although understandably some games are just not cut out for multiplayer, Mount and Blade would be amazing if a multiplayer co-op or pvp were possible while preserving the current gameplay.All in all, Mount and Blade is an amazing game and I highly recommend anyone who enjoys medieval combat and real-time strategy give it a chance!

												A truly great game.This game is great because :- It is free-roaming. You can explore to the edge of the world from the start of the game.- It is hack and slash game. content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Mount and Blade Warband is what every game should aspire to be. Sometimes you find a game that resonates with you, and goes beyond the game itself into a kind of meta-game and opens doors for you to do your own thing. Traditionally this is called sandbox - the problem with most sandbox titles is there is literally no direction. Warband avoid that weakness while still allowing you to feel the freedom and be inspired by it. The gameplay can be either simplified or incredibly unrelenting. The difficulty settings alone can make two games entirely different in every way. I enjoy playing an unstoppable warlord, a beast of death and carnage, a visage of loss and trauma to all who stand against me (I play on the easiest settings, which makes my troops take far less damage and inflict greater damage to enemy units). Or you can boost the difficulty and turn it into a fairly realistic army game, where your troops are just as easy to kill as the enemy. Many games will give you a sense of power, but few capture the feeling of charging down a hillside with 50 armored knights at your back and crashing into the enemy formation. For the price, you will not find a better game on planet earth. And this doesn't even begin to touch on all the mods created by a hugely inventive and dedicated community. Seriously, buy the game. Give it ten hours to learn the ropes and you will love it. If you don't, I will eat a shoe. (I will not eat a shoe)

												Lightly grease two baking trays. Pre-heat the oven to 220°C/425°F/Gas 7.Measure the flour and baking powder into a processor. Add the butter and process until a crumble, then add the sugar. Or make by hand by rubbing  the butter into the flour using your fingertips until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar.Beat the eggs together until blended and make up to a generous 300ml (1/2 pint) with the milk, then put about 2 tablespoons of the egg/milk aside in a cup for glazing the scones later. Gradually add the egg/milk mixture to the dry ingredients until you have a soft dough. It is far better that the scone mixture is on the wet side, sticking to your fingers, as the scones will rise better.Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface and flatten it out with your hand, or use a rolling pin, to a thickness of 1-2 cm (1/2 – ¾ inch). Use a 5 cm (2 inch) fluted cutter to stamp out the dough by pushing the cutter straight down into the dough (as opposed to twisting the cutter) then lift it straight out. This ensures that the scones will rise evenly and keep their shape. Gently push the remaining dough together, knead very lightly then re-roll and cut more scones out as before. Arrange the scones on the prepared baking trays and brush the tops with the reserved beaten egg/milk mixture to glaze. Bake for about 10-15 minutes or until the scones are well risen and golden. Cool on a wire rack, covered with a clean tea towel to keep them moist. Serve as fresh as possible, cut in half and spread generously with strawberry jam and top with a good spoonful of thick cream.How to make Scones, I really shouldn't need to persuade you why to buy this. content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game never fails providing me with the medieval atmosphere when I need it.Creating a new character in this game is a joy. When you just start creating your new character and send it to the world you are confronted with so many little decisions and adventures that you can take on many approaches. Be a soldier, a merchant, an outlaw or an adventurer - You can do it! The first 10-20 hours in any game are simply pure fun and all are unique in their way. Choosing your lord is exciting, joining a war is exciting, attending tournaments is exciting - it is all just great and has a unique feel that sits just right.However, the game seem to stop giving an effort at late-game, once you become strong enough to be a lord which is the one and only end-game scenario you can achieve, things become dull and repetetive. You will go about the same way from castle to castle as you slowly see the map turning your color. Expect no suprises, there will be none as politics barely exist and every war can be calculated and work as expected. Once you have the leverage over the game it will stay there and the game basically ends. The tactics are nice in this game. There are alot of ways to go about into battle and a combination of skill and strategy is needed to curve through a rough enemy. However the AI that is against you is pettiful at best and will always act similiar in terms of strategy, making it too easy to manipulate. there are only handful of scenarios and tactics you need to grasp and once you get familliar with them managing the battle becomes just another repetetive thing.The economy is also nice, however getting too much into it doesn't help you by much and you can probably profit better by just killing stuff. I still like it being there.Alot of design flaws... Auto resolved battles between AI is pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, it almost does not matter(if at all) which type of troops battle against which type of other troops or it the battle was a siege or an open battle. The AI gets more money than you by having cities and castles which breaks immersion and breaks their whole point of logical economic system and makes you feel as you are treated as a player rather than a character within the world.  Diplomacy is merely a joke, there is nothing interesting to do with prisoners. Being captured always ends the same way for you. Characters can't die. Killing bandits is too profitable and destroying their hideouts usually gives you nothing and stops their spawn which is anti intuitive and kills profit. I can go on for ever with the design flaws of this game, but it is expected from a small company.I mention all this flaws just to say I still recommend this game, because understanding flaws is easy for a reader but understanding the sense of wonder and atmosphere I get each time i open a new character is beyond simple words and I think you should buy the game to experience that.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Personally I would say this game is a great game, however, I feel there are a few details to know before buying this game. This game was made quite a good number of years ago and therefore the graphics are also a bit outdated so if that is something you can't get over I would not suggest buying this game. Also this game does have a bit steep of a learning curve but once you learn how to play it is definetly worth it.Now as to why I think this game is so good:Well first of all there is no story line which some would see as a bad idea but the way Warband uses it, it actually works. It allows for almost any possible course of action to achieve your own personal goals wether it be becoming rich, becoming King, or even marrying a noble lady. Secondly, the modding community is huge which is constantly adding mods that can increase your experience in the game or even add even more to said experience such as a mod called the Freelance mod which makes it so you are now able to play as a regular soldier in a Lords army. Thirdly, the multiplayer can have up to 200 players! How many "next generation" games do you hear of being able to have 200 players fighting eachother the the death in brutal and bloody combat. Fourthly, there is a DLC for this game which I have taken a particular interest in. This mod is the Napoleonic Wars DLC which allows you to play in multiplayer games as a soldier from the time period of Napoleon conquering Europe. This DLC while not having single player (although there is a mod that is coming out eventually that will have singleplayer) seems to draw you in with its organized communities. While the initial prospect of running around in a line and having to listen to orders may seem daunting especially considering that there is generally no space between each person in a line, I assure you it is actually a lot more fun then it sounds. Imagine being able to play as a artillery unit that is able to shoot at unit such as that or playing as cavalry and gloriously charging your enemy and cutting down any that get in your way. Or getting a reputation as a deadly sniper as a part of a skirmisher or line infantry regiment. With 200 players able to play in one server at once all these units can all be in the same server working together. So imagine marching towards enemy positions with artillery flying overhead and the cavalry charging past you while the skirmishers snipe important enemy personel.

												So I'm finally writing a review for Warband, one of the best games I've played for the longest time. 4 years now and I'm still coming back, but the thing is, I'm not playing the vanilla game. Oh no, this is one of the most mod-friendly games out there. The vanilla game is good, yes, I enjoyed it the first time I played, but mods just improve it so much that there really is no point to play the vanilla version again.Basically, in this game you got to become the ruler of the land. In vanilla, the land is called Calradia and you are destined to rule it. You make your character, pick your history and then basically start out as nobody. The world is open to you, you can be anyone in this game. A trader, a mercenary, a bandit, an explorer, a vassal to a monarch, but the path leads to one thing - becoming a ruler yourself.Also, there are mods which don't require you to become a ruler of anything, mods which are just open world battles, adventures, roleplaying or all of them combined.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game never fails providing me with the medieval atmosphere when I need it.Creating a new character in this game is a joy. When you just start creating your new character and send it to the world you are confronted with so many little decisions and adventures that you can take on many approaches. Be a soldier, a merchant, an outlaw or an adventurer - You can do it! The first 10-20 hours in any game are simply pure fun and all are unique in their way. Choosing your lord is exciting, joining a war is exciting, attending tournaments is exciting - it is all just great and has a unique feel that sits just right.However, the game seem to stop giving an effort at late-game, once you become strong enough to be a lord which is the one and only end-game scenario you can achieve, things become dull and repetetive. You will go about the same way from castle to castle as you slowly see the map turning your color. Expect no suprises, there will be none as politics barely exist and every war can be calculated and work as expected. Once you have the leverage over the game it will stay there and the game basically ends. The tactics are nice in this game. There are alot of ways to go about into battle and a combination of skill and strategy is needed to curve through a rough enemy. However the AI that is against you is pettiful at best and will always act similiar in terms of strategy, making it too easy to manipulate. there are only handful of scenarios and tactics you need to grasp and once you get familliar with them managing the battle becomes just another repetetive thing.The economy is also nice, however getting too much into it doesn't help you by much and you can probably profit better by just killing stuff. I still like it being there.Alot of design flaws... Auto resolved battles between AI is pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, it almost does not matter(if at all) which type of troops battle against which type of other troops or it the battle was a siege or an open battle. The AI gets more money than you by having cities and castles which breaks immersion and breaks their whole point of logical economic system and makes you feel as you are treated as a player rather than a character within the world.  Diplomacy is merely a joke, there is nothing interesting to do with prisoners. Being captured always ends the same way for you. Characters can't die. Killing bandits is too profitable and destroying their hideouts usually gives you nothing and stops their spawn which is anti intuitive and kills profit. I can go on for ever with the design flaws of this game, but it is expected from a small company.I mention all this flaws just to say I still recommend this game, because understanding flaws is easy for a reader but understanding the sense of wonder and atmosphere I get each time i open a new character is beyond simple words and I think you should buy the game to experience that.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Personally I would say this game is a great game, however, I feel there are a few details to know before buying this game. This game was made quite a good number of years ago and therefore the graphics are also a bit outdated so if that is something you can't get over I would not suggest buying this game. Also this game does have a bit steep of a learning curve but once you learn how to play it is definetly worth it.Now as to why I think this game is so good:Well first of all there is no story line which some would see as a bad idea but the way Warband uses it, it actually works. It allows for almost any possible course of action to achieve your own personal goals wether it be becoming rich, becoming King, or even marrying a noble lady. Secondly, the modding community is huge which is constantly adding mods that can increase your experience in the game or even add even more to said experience such as a mod called the Freelance mod which makes it so you are now able to play as a regular soldier in a Lords army. Thirdly, the multiplayer can have up to 200 players! How many "next generation" games do you hear of being able to have 200 players fighting eachother the the death in brutal and bloody combat. Fourthly, there is a DLC for this game which I have taken a particular interest in. This mod is the Napoleonic Wars DLC which allows you to play in multiplayer games as a soldier from the time period of Napoleon conquering Europe. This DLC while not having single player (although there is a mod that is coming out eventually that will have singleplayer) seems to draw you in with its organized communities. While the initial prospect of running around in a line and having to listen to orders may seem daunting especially considering that there is generally no space between each person in a line, I assure you it is actually a lot more fun then it sounds. Imagine being able to play as a artillery unit that is able to shoot at unit such as that or playing as cavalry and gloriously charging your enemy and cutting down any that get in your way. Or getting a reputation as a deadly sniper as a part of a skirmisher or line infantry regiment. With 200 players able to play in one server at once all these units can all be in the same server working together. So imagine marching towards enemy positions with artillery flying overhead and the cavalry charging past you while the skirmishers snipe important enemy personel.

												Lightly grease two baking trays. Pre-heat the oven to 220°C/425°F/Gas 7.Measure the flour and baking powder into a processor. Add the butter and process until a crumble, then add the sugar. Or make by hand by rubbing  the butter into the flour using your fingertips until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar.Beat the eggs together until blended and make up to a generous 300ml (1/2 pint) with the milk, then put about 2 tablespoons of the egg/milk aside in a cup for glazing the scones later. Gradually add the egg/milk mixture to the dry ingredients until you have a soft dough. It is far better that the scone mixture is on the wet side, sticking to your fingers, as the scones will rise better.Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface and flatten it out with your hand, or use a rolling pin, to a thickness of 1-2 cm (1/2 – ¾ inch). Use a 5 cm (2 inch) fluted cutter to stamp out the dough by pushing the cutter straight down into the dough (as opposed to twisting the cutter) then lift it straight out. This ensures that the scones will rise evenly and keep their shape. Gently push the remaining dough together, knead very lightly then re-roll and cut more scones out as before. Arrange the scones on the prepared baking trays and brush the tops with the reserved beaten egg/milk mixture to glaze. Bake for about 10-15 minutes or until the scones are well risen and golden. Cool on a wire rack, covered with a clean tea towel to keep them moist. Serve as fresh as possible, cut in half and spread generously with strawberry jam and top with a good spoonful of thick cream.How to make Scones, I really shouldn't need to persuade you why to buy this. Just do it.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2012
												Mount & Blade: Warband is one of the best games I have played in a while. The combat is solid, the factions have their own strengths and weaknesses and the battles are hectic and massive. This is one of the only games I have seen that actually lets you be part of the battle instead of some sort of skygod. Did I say the battles were awesome yet? If I did let me say it again, the battles can range from small skirmishes to large scale battles. In addition to the field battles you also have the ability to seige castles and cities and if that isn't your style, why not raid a few peasent villages for loot and plunder!There are countless things I could say that are good about Mount & Blade: Warband including the Mod support. Like Game of Thrones? The have a mod for that. Want the game to take place in Feudal Europe? They have a mod for that as well! There are a bunch of other mods for the game so the replay value is extremely high.The game does have a couple of downsides though.One of them being the graphics. If you are looking for a visually stunning game this may not be for you. Along with that there is very little voice acting. The only voice acting you will hear are the warcrys of the soliders on the battlefield and the bandits as well as some farmers, so don't be expecting Morgan Freeman or Jennifer Hale as voice actors and voice actresses.The early game is quite difficult as well (or at least it was for me.) You will constantly be attacked by Bandits, Sea Raiders and the like until you amass a big enough force to take them and then still they will  sometimes attack you.But if you can look past these flaws I think you will have a great time. I know I did! Thank you for reading my review for the great game and I am sorry if this review isn't that great as it is my first review!Thanks for your time.Best regards-A Crazed Engineer

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
 A brilliant RPG Just picture a vast continent filled with 22 cities and 48 castles each with several villages split amongst 6 factions constantly at war fighting for control and it's all your playground. Do you play the noble knight, swearing homage to a lord and defending the poor peasants? How about a bandit pillaging the villages and raiding trade caravans to line your pockets? Or maybe you have aspirations for the throne. Build an army and carve out an empire under your own banner. These are but a few options that you can take.There are a sizeable amount of skill options that allow the creation of many types of characters from the heavily armoured knight to the swift horse archer.The game has a rather steep learning curve however practice and patience will give results.The difficulty is easily customised to your preference from the options menu.The graphics are dated by today's standards and there are still some bugs.The multiplayer is still active at the time of writing with many dedicated players.It offers multiple game modes / Deathmatch(free for all) / Team Deathmatch / Siege (teams attack and defend castles) / Capture the Flag / Battle (no respawns).The community is a mixed bunch, with about an equal split between friendly and ill mannered players.There is a vast active modding community that offers players the ability to change the settings and mechanics of the game. Genkokujo(Sengoku jidai era of Japan), A Clash of Kings(Game of Thrones) Anno Domini(13th Century Europe), Just to name a few. PROS ~Vast Customisation ~Re-playability~Modding~Skill based Gameplay CONS ~Learning Curve~Hit and Miss Community~Dated Graphics

												Over a thousand hours poured into the game. I decided its time to say exactly why I've spent this much time playing it.Warband is a game that attempts many things, being a medieval combat sim, a sandbox, a RPG of sorts, and much more. It has many strengths and a few weaknesses.PROS:Strong modding community. Infinite replay value. 												I'm going to point out only the pros and cons because i have people to send to the gulag and don't have the time to write a full review, yet.Pros:-Immersive realistic medieval world;-Amazing combat system;-Large map with a good instant map creator for battles;-Excellent faction diplomacy mechanics (for an fps rpg);-Large choice of weapons and armour, that  match existing kinds of armour that existed at the time.-Ease to mod;-Excellent mechanics for creating parties and armies, with realistic modifiers such as morale, salary, etc..;-Massive battles up to 300 people at a time, with tons of bodies that stay;-Amazing siege system with victory or defeat bringing criteria such as remaining food in the city/castle, how long to build siege equipment-Doesn't require a powerfull computer;-Tons of great mods available;-No capitalist foreign intervention;-Freedom of choice relative to your history, what you do, what you become, you can shape the fait of kingdoms, drive them to be empires or erase them from history, become a dreadfull bandit or a renown lord, you can even found your own kingdom; -Good multiplayer includes servers with up to 200 slots, amazing maps and game modes, and tons of fun, especially in a clan;Cons:-Graphics;-Game instability due to the insalation of mods or add-ons;-Once you conquer Calradia there is not much else to do;-Singleplayer will get you hooked up for 200 hours before you go buy Napoleonic Wars and forget about Native;-Swadians knights=rage+frustration;-"Overpowered" weapons in multiplayer don't allow for good balance in matches, especially sieges;-Hard to learn combat since singleplayer bots play in a different style from 90% of players who won't give you a chance in the game and will constantly abuse you;-No russian bias;9.7/10 would m&b again.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Mount and Blade: Warband is a sandbox RPG set in the fictional land of Calradia. This game is certainly in my top five favorite games of all time, and my Steam in-game hours tell that story. This game is full of nostalgic elements which make up for its graphical and other technical shortcomings.   M&B: Warband is one of a kind. It has immersive gameplay, sophisticated yet simple troop managment, a vast variety of weapons and armor, multiple factions, marriages, relationships, companions, wandering poets, belligerent drunks, great combat mechanics, tournaments, enterprises, and nostalgic, humorous dialogue during encounters with lords and bandits alike.   With so many options as to how to play the game, this game has a high replay value, you can play multiplayer, custom battles, be a wondering scoundrel, a bandit raider, an honorable gentleman, a hated vagabond, or even a lord of an existing kingdom or king of all Calradia!     This game has a few downsides however. It takes many hours to learn the game mechanics well, and hundreds of hours to successfuly conquer Calradia (if you even dare attempt it). It also lacks graphicaly and at times lacks some immersive elements that many would enjoy (mods can do wonders, however).   If you want a game with medieval lore, a great modding community (I would recommend the "Diplomacy" mod is you would like more options as a lord when it comes to diplomatic relations and such), addictive gameplay, and full of challenging economic, diplomatic, and military dynamics, look no further than Mount and Blade: Warband!

												Mount and blade warband is a game that drops you into a land where you must pick one of 7 different nations. At first when picking my character's backstory I realized that your past effects the way you communicate with nobles and people, also determines you skills on the battlegrounds.When I got this game I thought it would just be a game that would concentrate only on combat and nothing much else. content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
He stood and observed the audience with tired, almost lifeless eyes. Cleaning his throat, he started his speech:- Today it is my third day without Mount & Blade: Warband. 70... 78 hours to be precise...The audience was shocked. The silence rested in the room for few seconds until someone on the left started a timid clap, leading the rest of the room. Everybody was marvelled - how could someone start playing Mount & Blade: Warband and quit for 78 hours?! That was almost beyond comprehension.He said, with a half smile on his lips but the fatigue in his soul still clear in his eyes:- Thank you, thank you. It is hard, but I am struggling. After 3 years and a half, I believe... my brothers, I believe I will never look back.A young boy could be seen whispering in his neighbour's ears- Do you think I'll get there some day? Do you think I will manage to stop playing one day?to which the other boy replied- We can only dream... he has shown us that there is hope...The audience went nuts and clapping and shouting of joy; that's what they have been waiting for, for a hope, that that young man had just unannouncedly brought to them all. With a gesture of his hands, he urged the audience to quiet down, his life slowly coming back to him at that moment, the smile brightening up in his face, and then he said- My brothers! I am free! I shall never play Mount & Blade: Warband anylonger. I have prevailed.Filled the hearts with that hope that day, that young man has never returned the MBW Addiction Centre. Two days from that he would find out that he was very wrong - he answered the call to save Calradia, and returned to Mount & Blade: Warband, and was once again showered by the glory of the battlefield.- One does not simple stop playing Mount & Blade: Warbandhe thought. Yet this time he was almost right for that was almost the truth. None, none of them could possibly rid their lives from Mount & Blade: Warband ever again, until that day in which a greater glory would await.Until Mount & Blade: Bannerlord, their souls was bound - and they knew it.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I decided to write a serious review for this game to show my respect and unfortunately, disappointment for warband.So the concept is simple, ally with a faction until strong enough, then create your own faction to take over the world. The good1. RealismThis game is brutal, you spend hours and hours grinding for the perfect army and then accidentally save at the wrong time or activate realism mode. You lose your army and become a prisoner, when released, only to be beat up b the pirates you once pwned on a daily basis.2. ModsThere are literally thousands of mods in this game that completely revolutionize your experience of warband. After combing through 5 total conversion mods, I conclude that the modding community for this game is very talented and dedicated, mods or warband potentially could give it hours more of content.3. CombatAction in this game isn't exactly the selling point of this game, but not too shabby. Stradegy, though often mentioned in reviews, is not really its highlight. After much thought, the most effective stratedgy seems to always be having the cavalry flank, and infantry in front of the archers as shields. The intricate commands offered by the game gives chance for experimentation with the game's combat mechanics. The Bad:1. Lack of incentivesThere is no goal of this game other than (I'm assuming) to conquer the factions. Now even if that itself were a reasonable incentive, I feel like the lack of storyline in this game makes it hard to sit through hours of combat grinding and trading to obtain a bigger army. Addition of smaller, story related objectives would motivate me better than tedious grinding, doing the guild master quests' over and over again. The others:1. GraphicsAgain, no the selling point of this game, but acceptable as the game isn't dependent of graphics but rather its creative playstyles and hours of tinkering with the game, therefore making graphics only a small portion of this review.2. WorldThere should be more characters in the game. The first few hours might appear fresh with different quests given by every king, guild master and village elder, but very soon players realize they are just the same quests. Though the world seems lively and flexible to the player's play style, soon, merchant players will realize there are trade routes that always guarantee profit, players that make money off prisoners will realize most battles are simply repetitions as long as one is powerful enough. Though the game promises diversity, the world of warband limits this features.Verdict:A great bang for the buck, I personally have spent a few dozen happy hours on it. However, the game is rather dry in late game.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Mount & Blade: Warband is one of those classic gems which will stand the test of time for decades to come. For me, it is much like my memories of Morrowind: nothing but grand, incredible adventures and tale after tale unique only to me.As far as I know, there are no other games out there that are directly comparable to the genre of Warband. In a single game you have grand strategy, tactical combat, action hack and slash, lite city simulation and RPG all wrapped in one awesome game. Everything about it will pull you in further and further much like the “one-more-turn” syndrome experience from games like Civilization.In the briefest of summaries: you raise and command an army, and then choose how to use it. You can take over the world, marry into royalty, freelance, help overthrow a ruler, become a trading mogul, or even play politics with the warring factions. You can do just about whatever you want, and all of it is absolutely fantastic. A must buy title for sure.

Posted: September 13, 2016
												Mount & Blade: Warband is an amazing game, but I think the vanilla game is a bit too slow-paced even though that might be a good thing since realisticly no one can become a King or a Queen in a day.I do like the native version of the game, but getting captured by bandits or deserters in the early game can be a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and the ammount of gold you get from missions can be quite small. Of course if you get enough renown you can become a vassal, but that just means you are working under a King who wont give you towns or castles untill you have a ton of renown. (And that can take alot of time, depressingly so.)"Why did you give this game a thumps up then?"Well, there IS a thing called cheats in the options before you start the game, so that's one way to make the game more enjoyable, but you won't be able to get any achievements.I do personally perfer downloading a custom mod from the Workshop or the Mount & Blade: Warband Nexus.My personal favourite mod from the Workshop is the Vexed Native Mod by Vechs. The mod basicly speeds up the training time of troops, gives you more gold and renown from missions and adds a few more practical options into town and castle menus.In the end the Native version is a solid 8 for me, but adding cheats or a mod that helps you progress through the game faster ups it to a 10.

Posted: October 8, 2014
Mount & Blade: Warband  Field Rating Review   Graphics 6 While the game definitely does not shine in environmental textures, the differences in armor are enough to feel the satisfaction of getting new gear. The animations are also relatively smooth and intuitive.   Gameplay 8.5 With a combat system not seen in any other game, Mount & Blade sets itself apart. Ride your horse into battle and cut down your enemies at the head of your army (or small warband), meet them face to face as a footsoldier, or pick them off from afar as an archer, the choice is yours. The game maintains a classic RPG skill system which allows you to manage not only your main character, but ever other secondary character in your party. You will never have as much fun running your sword through your foes than you will in Mount & Blade: Warband.   Story N/A Honestly, there's really not much of a story to this one, as it treats itself as a "craft your own tale" sort of story. Which is perfect for their goal.  Multiplayer 6 Where the multiplayer of Mount & Blade: Warband shines is in its mods. Look into them, you will not regret it.   Replayability 9 I have played Mount & Blade since the days of its beta. And still I consistently find myself returning for more, to tell myself a new story, or to simply enjoy the unique combat once again.   Overall 7.9/10 One of the most satisfying things in gaming, to me, is starting at the bottom of the ladder and working your way up. Visually seeing the increase of strength in your character and their advancement, be it through armor, or the number of followers you have. Mount & Blade: Warband does this is spades, and it is glorious. Ever wanted to command hundreds of men? Ever wanted to have an elite small force? Ever wanted to siege castle and throw down a king? Then Mount & Blade: Warband is the game for you.With fantasticly unique combat, wonderful rpg points elements, and a great set of mods which make the game that much more extensive, you will find yourself coming back to Warband again and again. If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:The TipsterYou are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:  The Tipster
