content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Mount and Blade: Warband is an Action RPG with Kingdom Sim elements that drops you into the land of Calradia, a low fantasy land of feudal nations warring for supremacy. It is readily apparent that Sid Meier's Pirates! served as a primary inspiration for this game, as it plays like a more combat oriented version with a medieval setting instead.To get the negatives out of the way, I'll start by mentioning the low production values. As the screenshots betray, this isn't the most beautiful game out there. There is little voice acting, and what is there does not stand out as memorable. The interface design is spartan and pragmatic, with little in the way of flourish. There are strange design choices (such as siege battles that only have one ladder for the attackers to climb) that can result in an unbalanced play experience. However, if you are the type of gamer that values new and compelling experiences above production values then you will be hard pressed to find a game that fills this niche better than Mount and Blade: Warband. You start by creating a character through a series of basic background choices that determine starting stat values as well as equipment and other odds and ends. You are then unceremoniously dropped into the land of Calradia, with the world your oyster. You can go around recruiting volunteers to fight as a mercenary band, fight in tournaments for money and presitge, and eventually become a vassal to a king or even start your own faction. There are a lot of systems at play, and it would be difficult to condense them into this review. The main draw for many players, however, is the sizable amount of quality mods available thanks to the passionate fan community surrounding the game. Once you've got your fill of the vanilla game, you have a large choice of mods that expand the game in many different directions, such as fleshing out the kingdom management aspect with new diplomacy options, the ability to play as a common foot soldier in a Lord's army, and even total conversions that transport the game into both original worlds and those from licensed properties. As you can see, I fully recommend this game to anyone that is tempted by anything you read in both this review and the others. If you still aren't convinced, you can visit the TaleWorlds website and download the trial game to get a feel for it and see if it's something you'd be into. The trial features everything the full game does, just with a level cap, so you can try different things and see if something clicks.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
 General Overview I've always wanted to play a medieval themed role playing game. I saw my friend playing it, so I decided to give it a go. It was one of the best decisions I've made in a while. The premise of the game is that you start out alone in the kingdom of Calradia where numerous factions fight for the ultimate throne. You can join a faction as a mercenary then work your way up, or help someone overthrow their king. Once you are affiliated with a faction or already own one, you'll be at war against other kings sooner or later. For you to conquer Calradia, you need to seige the enemy forts and towns to conquer them one by one. You have to recruit your own men from various towns for war. After battle, you and your men will gain exp and eventually be able to upgrade. The game itself is very heavily focused on combat, so it feels to me as if it lacks depth to other aspects, such as kingdom management. If you're a fan of combat based games however, this is a great game for you. The melee fights are very responsive, the hitboxes are good, and it just feels right. You also have a fairly diverse range of weapons to choose from, such as crossbows, throwing axes, lances, maces, and longswords. This game does have its downsides though, For the most part, the game can be very dull and repetitve when you near the end of the game. You can do quests for the townfolks and talk to various characters, but you are going to be fighting someone at the end of the day.But don't let this deter you from buying this game. I've already spent well over 100 hours playing this game, and I haven't even tried out workshop contents or multiplayer. Despite its lack of content in other areas, it still does great in what it focuses on. If you like medieval action, you should definitely give this game a try, especially during sales!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game is amazing; in fact, all the Mount and Blade games are amazing. The fact that you are reading this instead of playing it or buying it is very odd. Basically the M&B games are realistic medieval simulators, in that you can essentially do whatever your little heart desires. SINGLEPLAYER: Want to be a soldier on the frontlines? Go ahead and join an army(considering all of the factions and randomness(well, not really random; there is a whole slew of political reasoning behind the relations, but I won't get into that) of factions' relations, you should have no problem becoming an infantryman in an army). Want to be a peaceful farmer/business-owner/lord/peasant/guild member? Sure, go on ahead. There is literally no end to what you can do, considering how the campaign really never ends. There are no cinematics, you create your own story, which is why M&B is so damn good! You can literally do anything, with great customization options(character/equipment/residence/armor/weapons etc). Oh yeah, I almost forgot; you can command an army of your own! It is so cool to see your army gain ranks(whether it be through hire or volunteer), and with that army comes the responsibility of food, salaries, and rest. If your army doesn't get all of those, men will desert their posts and lose morale. If you need food, you can be an honest man and buy some, or you can raid a village and steal and plunder; hell, you can even steal a farmer's cattle if you want. There is nothing you can't do in this game, and it is simply amazing.CUSTOM BATTLES: Yes, there are custom battles. And yes, they are awesome! When I first loaded up M&B Warband, that is the first thing I noticed, and I literally played them for hours. You get to choose what map you'd like to play(there are a few options), what game mode (battle, defend the castle, attack the castle), your character and faction (at least a dozen different characters and all the factions from singleplayer), and how many men you want in your army (at most, 200 on each side, but there are plenty of mods which can increase the max amount up to 1,000+). Multiplayer: Don't even get me started on this! It is so amazing. There are a good amount of maps (a lot of them are user-created), a good amount of modes (battle, siege, conquest, duel, deathmatch, etc.), and a lot of players online (4,000+ at some moments!) Some of the maps/servers allow up to 200 players in a single match, which can create a crazy, chaotic, amazing experience! It is a must play for fans of multiplayer. I can honestly play multiplayer for hours on end, and it is just great. It follows the Counter-Strike formula by having you pick a class (usually archer, crossbowman, infantry, calvary, etc.), starting you off with a certain amount of money, and has you purchase equipment for battle. Kills = money, and usually, money means more kills, haha.COMMUNITY: The community for M&B is simply amazing. Tens of thousands of players, hundreds of mods, and overall, a dedicated fanbase. The mods are my favorite part by far. It basically makes M&B a hundred games in one. There are so many good ones; for example, M&B has a total conversion Star Wars mod, which makes literally everything in M&B convert to its Star Wars counterpart (character modles, map, weapons, armor, textures, singleplayer, custom battle, factions, dialogue, etc.)All in all, you can't go wrong with M&B. I definitely recommend the M&B collection, which includes all of the M&B games (I got mine at Target for $10!). It is quite possibly the best PC game on the market right now. It literally never ends, which = unlimited replayability (also remember the strong community, the custom battles, the multiplayer, etc.) Do yourself a favor and treat yourself to one of the best PC games in existence!

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Awesome game. Many more hours than on record in the betas and pre-steam versions (~300).First the bad stuff:---------------------------------- Graphics aren't awesome. If you're looking for the next shiny game, this isn't for you.- Dialogues and menu system is dated. Don't let this scare you away! They look rather silly, but they are functional.- Sound effects are sub-par, but iconic. "Aarrrr, I will drink from your skull!"- Seeing a trend here? Don't play this game if you are looking for shiny fluff.- Rough start. No instructionAnd now for the good:---------------------------------- Combat system is epic. This is the gold standard for medieval combat systems.- Horseback combat! Find a horse, keep moving, stay alive. Mount & Blade was the first game to properly implement horseback combat, and they perfected it.- If your sword/spear/arrow/axe looks like it cuts through someone's jugular, it actually cuts through their jugular, and that is so satisfying.- Directional attacks have to be blocked with directional blocks. This is the key to multiplayer combat. If they attack left, and you block right, you are d.e.a.d. Directional attacks and blocks are done using mouse movements. To attack from the left, move the mouse a bit to the left as you do your attack, and your sword will pull back to the left until you release the attack. Same for blocking.- Horses and men can die as separate entities, and can be a useful strategy.- Epic battles! Both multiplayer and singleplayer. Single-player battles can become enormous, with as many units as your PC can handle. Multiplayer battles are usually in the 20-40 player range. Just, so much fun. - Campaign is fun, but really long. I have never gotten close to becoming the Ruler of Calradia. I prefer to think of the single-player as a sandbox, and a great sandbox game at that. If you're goal-oriented, you might have trouble getting anywhere.- Multiplayer is a lot of fun, but also very punishing if you don't know what you're doing. Thankfully, I know what I'm doing, :) Practicing your swordplay, particularly blocking, is a must.- And have you read the negative reviews?? "Don't expect much playtime, it is a very boring game.  2,600.5 hrs on record"  lolTips for Single-player Recruits------------------------------------- Get on a horse, stay there, and keep moving.- There are 3 types of settlements: Castles, Villages, and Cities. Castles just store units. You can recruit volunteers at villages, the more rep with the village, the more recruits. Towns have shops, an inn, and tournaments. Heroes and sell swords can be recruited at the inn. You can compete in tournaments to gain gold and glory.- Recruit as many men as your party capacity allows. They will require food, so have some in your inventory or they will get angry.- Upgrade your army whenever you can- If something on the map is chasing you, that means they think they can win the battle. Run.- The more men you have, the slower your party will move, so a small party can typically outrun a larger party. The more mounted units in your army, the faster you will move.- Aim for the head. Every weapon deals more damage if you hit them in the head.- Lances have 2 attack modes: Your usual stabbing action, and a "Couched Lance" that deals significantly more (x4) damage. To do this attack, in single-player, while on horseback, with your lance out, your spear will automatically drop when you reach a certain minimum velocity (DON'T PRESS THE ATTACK BUTTON). While your lance is in this lowered position, ram the end of the spear into an enemy and they will almost certainly be instantly killed (or their shield will break). Be very careful if you see an enemy approaching you at speed on horseback, because if they have a lance out, you could instantly die, regardless of your current health and difficulty settings! In multiplayer, you need to lower the lance manually by pressing X by default.- Use keys 0-9 to select units during combat, then F1-F8 to give orders to the selected units. It can be very helpful to climb the nearest hill and tell your archers to stay there while you fight in the valley below.- Press Backspace during combat to get a bit of a UI for controlling your various unit types
